runs.comm: some outswing for Lee, and Jayawardene leaves it alone outside off, just getting his eye in
outswing again, MJ plays with soft hands, but straight back to Lee
MJ makes room this time and cuts, it awkwardly bounces just in front of Steve Smith at cover-point, who gets a hand to it, but the ball ricochets for a single
strays into the pads, and is clipped away for a single
MJ seems to be in the mood, makes room early again, gets under a length ball, and lofts it over mid-on without seeming to hit it hard at all. Lovely timing, hit through the line
now he gets one short and wide enough to cut, and gets a single to third man
tossed up outside off, pushed to cover
another flighted delivery, Jayawardene goes for a big sweep, and is beaten
pushes this one through even as Jayawardene backs away, cramps him for a room, the inside edge doesn't make it to the stumps
stands his ground this time, and gets a short and wide delivery to cut away for four

whoa, that was close, wonder why they didn't appeal properly... this seems to be the arm ball that cramps Jayawardene even as he is backing away to try and chop it square. Seemed to me to have hit the pad first, dead in front of stumps, but Australia are more worried about preventing the leg-bye
another arm ball, this one actually turned in, and hits him in the pad, but is also headed down the leg side
Timber... The yorker. Jayawardene backs away again, Lee goes full, and in front of leg, Jayawardene gets bat onto it, but only to guide it to the the off stump
Lee welcomes him with a bouncer, but well down the leg side
full and fast, but into the pads, concedes the leg-bye
back of a length, on off, Dilshan plays with an open face, can't beat cover
this is short, there is no room, but Dilshan manages to cut it powerfully to third man, where a bad bounce results in a fumble for Johnson, and a second run
It's a harsh harsh game... This is a superb bouncer, quick, at the throat, Dilshan is late into the shot, but the top edge sails past the pulled-in boundary ropes behind fine leg
Dilshan now rubs salt into the top-edged-six wound... what a top shot this, it's full, just outside off, the bat jams down on it with an open face, and it goes hurtling across, past point for four
a gentle loosener, short outside off, cut hard into the ground, but can't get past the strong square field on the off side
short, into the ribs, Chandimal doesn't hold back on the pull, gets a single to long leg

slightly slower delivery, pushed between mid-off and extra cover. A near collision between Johnson and Dilshan there. Dilshan is not happy, but it's the batsman's responsibility to run around the bowler
clears the front leg and swings hard at a full delivery, bounces into the pitch, and beats mid-on to go for four. This is a superb start for Sri Lanka
again, the vintage T20 technique of clearing the front leg and swinging through or across the line. This one is across, and goes square on the leg side for another four
another swing, but this time the extra bounce beats him outside off
angled into the pads, concedes a leg-bye
front leg out of the way again, pulls, straight to midwicket where a fumble allows them the single
slower short ball, Dilshan is through the shot when it hits him in the ribs. Another leg-bye
another slower ball, nearly gets Chandimal with it. The limp shot falls in front of extra cover
another slower ball, full this time, and is placed in the covers
the quicker one this time, full and wide outside off, beats Chandimal drive
full on off, driven with an open face, amazing how he manufactures room. A fumble from Watson at extra cover allows them the single
short and quick, there is room, though, but Chandimal is beaten by the bounce as he tries a big cut

Hit wicket! I don't remember any hit-wickets in T20 internationals. This might well be a first. It's a length ball on the pads, but the extra pace forces him deep into the crease, the bat comes down real late, and the over-balanced Chandimal's front leg goes across and hits the stumps. It takes the Aussies a while to realise they have got a wicket
first signs of good Australian fielding as White at midwicket makes the save off a good drive from Sangakkara
on the pads, worked away into the on side
driven with an open face again, but can't beat cover-point
worked around the corner for a single
risky single after hitting it straight to point, but Hussey's throw is wide, and Haddin has to try and flick it behind his back. A better throw, and Sanga was gone
some turn on this, but well down the leg side
pushed into the covers for one
charges at him and drives him down to long-off for one
comes down the track, and pushes this down to long-on
Dilshan misses the sweep and is hit right in front of the stumps, but the extra bounce means there isn't even an appeal
angled across the left-hand batsman, and it beats Sanga's drive
walks into this shot, and drives it wide of long-off for one
slower ball gone wrong, a delicious little full toss wide outside off, and he smashes it for four to extra cover
another slower one gone wrong, a wide down the leg side, with the fine leg up!

good sharp offcutter, tucks Dilshan up, and he has to go back and keep the ball away from the stumps even as Sanga is charging for a single. He comes, nearly shakes hands with Dilshan, and makes it back safely
pulls, beaten, it's either off the leading edge or off the pad, goes fine of third man, and they come back for the second
short, into the ribs, emphatically pulled away for four. Along the ground
tossed up, accurate, defended back
the slog sweep along the ground, what a hard hit, no chance for deep square leg to come around
placed wide of long-on but will get just the single
makes room, goes inside-out, finds extra cover... on the bounce
pushed quietly down to long-on
short and wide, cut away for a single
accurate legbreak, Sanga taps it back
comes down the track and drives this to long-off for one
fullish legbreak, Dilshan looks to cut, and is beaten
full, on the pads, Dilshan forces this to extra cover... another dot
driven down the ground now, gets a single to long-off
beautiful shot... Comes down the track, makes sure he is right to the pitch of the ball, and lofts this dead straight over the bowler's head
Dilshan tries the scoop first ball, but is hit in the shoulder, and still gets a leg-bye
length ball, driven on the up, gets a single to long-off
slower short ball, beats Dilshan's short-arm pull

winds up for a big shot, the ball jags back in, Dilshan's bat comes down on it the last moment. And wait a moment. Watson lets the throw rip at Dilshan's face, he fends it off with his glove, and Australia appeal for a run-out/obstruction to fielders. Turned down, and rightly so. Dilshan never left his crease too. Poor form, Australia. It was clearly evasive action, and Dilshan never left the crease, leave alone intending a single
worked around the corner for a single
full, on the pads, flicked away fine, and they steal the second. A slightly wide throw from O'Keefe allows them to do so
on the front foot a touch too early, gets a top edge on a short-of-a-length delivery, but avoids the fielders and gets a couple of runs
oh lovely shot, on the up, high elbow, and over mid-off. That was one for the photographers
another Sanga trademark, walks across the stumps, and flicks this off his toes, over square leg - brings up 50 for the partnership
wide down the leg side now
back of a length, around off, the rare defensive shot
tucked into the on side, doesn't get a run
driven on the up, but straight to cover
another open-face drive, hit hard into ground, White has to stretch to get a hand to it. They take a single
what a soft dismissal, lot of premeditation in it as he walks down the wicket. The ball is not nearly full enough, and is also the slower one, and Sanga ends up chipping it straight to midwicket
worked wide of midwicket for a single
length ball around off, driven to long-off for one
jumps across the stumps to drop this into the on side for one
short legbreak, outside off, the turn cramps Mendis, who can't get it past point
reverse sweep here, takes from what his leg stump would be, and places it between point and short third man
worked around the corner for another single
cut away in front of square for one
nudges into the leg side for another single
the powerful sweep from leg-stump line, gets just the single
Ahh the scoop. Like it is ice cream on Saturday evening. Splendid. He covers his head with his arms, and flicks it straight over the keeper's head
pulled away to deep square leg
another pull, square of the long leg, and comes back for the second
pull with the front leg in the air, and this is hardly a long hop. He goes over midwicket. Disdainful
just the ball to bowl with fine leg up, a yorker wide of off, beats his jab
this attempted yorker is a bit of a full toss, and the thick edge yields a single to third man
driven square on the off side, gets a single
slower short ball, gets the mistimed pull out of it, but it falls wide of the diving D Hussey at deep square leg
the slower legcutter, starts well wide of off, and is called a wide as it beats the bat
this is nearly a sweep, helped by the slower deliveries, opens up the front leg, gets down on a knee, and places this past midwicket

another slower ball, another sweep. Dilshan is playing Hastings like he would do a spinner. What a top shot, too, along the ground, and beats deep square. Fifty off 37 for Dilshan. Wild cheers, and why not?

this is a reverse-flick-cum-pull-cum-scoop. I don't know what to call this awesome shot. Dilshan is going for his scoop, sees a slower bouncer, turns the bat face around, and pulls this between the keeper and third man
this one is asking to be spanked, a tempting little full toss, and Dilshan flat-bats it to midwicket
goes for the wide yorker, Mendis gets close to the line, and opens the face on it, guiding past point. This is superb T20 batting. Five fours off the last six balls
another wide yorker, Mendis is beaten while going on side, but this is too wide, and is called
slower short ball, beats the pull, hits him on the pad, but it is bouncing over the stumps
full and around off, played with an open face - another 50-run partnership
full toss outside off, driven to sweeper-cover
another full toss, Dilshan misses out too, gets a single to mid-off
three strikes and four! Third full toss in a row, and Mendis drives this one square for four
don't gape disbelievingly when you read this: Dilshan has slog-swept Watson for a six. Watson can't believe it either. Just brilliant premeditation and execution
short ball, not much width, but Dilshan's wrists manufacture immense power on cut shots, and this has gone for four too
full ball, Dilshan clears the front leg, and heaves this to long-on for one
high full toss - not high enough to be called - the top edge falls between midwicket and long-on
a perfectly respectable yorker, but Dilshan stabs at it, hard into the ground, and then over point for another four. This is some pasting
another slog-sweep! Low full toss, Dilshan's front leg gets out of the way, and he lofts this over midwicket. Wonder if Watson regrets that throw at Dilshan's face
full toss outside off, gets a thick edge to third man
can't do much with a yorker on middle and leg, he keeps it out, though, and steals a single
slower ball, slogged down to wide of long-on, and they hustle back for the second
another full toss, driven down to long-off for one
full, fast, wide of off, Dilshan can't make contact with this one
a perfect yorker at the base of leg stump. Dilshan keeps it out, and takes a single
tries the scoop again, but is beaten by the slower bouncer. Called one for the over
old-fashioned Twenty20 slog, helps that this is a length ball, and he opens up the stance to send it over long-on. Into the 90s now. Hmm

This is absolute toying around with the bowling. Dilshan stands with an open stance, across the stumps, he wants to go over leg side, and a clue less Johnson serves up a gentle long hop, and is pulled out of sight

what a way to get to maiden Twenty20 international hundred, with the trademark scoop, it's not connected very well, but enough to clear fine leg. Dilshan leaps for joy, the crowd is going crazy, and everybody barring the Aussie fielders is loving it. White applauds too
another short ball, top-edged over midwicket, and somehow even this goes for four. Australia absolutely clueless
full, angled across him, beats the bat, Dilshan doesn't try the bye
